abstract.p: Lumbar puncture (LP) is known to result in complications. Procedure skills should be taught and evaluated more effectively to improve health care quality. Validated checklists are central to teaching and assessing procedural skills. The results of the first step of the validation of an adult LP checklist are described. A comprehensive literature review of articles published on LP did not yield a checklist validated by the Delphi method. A modified Delphi technique, involving a panel of 9 experts, was used to develop a 20-item LP checklist for teaching and assessing LP, the first step in the validation process. The internal consistency coefficient using Cronbach’s αwas 0.79. The authors used a modified Delphi method to develop a checklist for teaching and assessing LP. For this checklist to become further validated, it should be implemented and studied in the simulation and clinical environments.

body.p: Lumbar puncture (LP) is an invasive procedure that is commonly performed in inpatient and outpatient settings for both diagnostic and therapeutic purposes. Emergency department physicians, neurologists, hospitalists, anesthesiologists, and primary care providers all frequently perform this procedure. It is a core competency for the Society of Hospital Medicine for hospitalists practicing in the United States,1 for graduate medical learners in the United Kingdom,2 and for physicians3 and physician assistants who work in the emergency department.4

Complications of LP include post-LP headache, infection (local or meningitis), bleeding, herniation, and damage to nerves or the spinal cord.5,6 Headache, the most common complication, has been recorded at frequencies ranging from 30% to 55%.7-10

Studies have demonstrated a lack of resident procedural skills. Lammers et al11 studied first-year emergency medicine residents and found that none met an LP competency performance standard. In another study, residents reported being uncomfortable managing complications in 35% of LP procedures performed.12 Finally, Lirk et al13 found that 51% of anesthesia residents failed to correctly identify sites of puncture.

The authors’ literature search identified 5 manuscripts that included the use of an LP checklist. All were developed and vetted by expert faculty members or modified slightly from a previously published checklist.11,14-17

However, none of these studies used the modified Delphi technique to validate the checklist. The authors describe the results of the first step of the validation process for the development of a checklist for teaching and assessing LP in adults.

sec.title: Review of the Literature
sec.p: One author (EMJ) conducted a comprehensive literature review by searching Ovid MEDLINE 1990 to November 2011, Ovid MEDLINE in-process and other nonindexed citations 1990 to November 2011, and PubMed (only searched for status ahead of print publications in November 2011) to identify English language articles published on checklists used for teaching or measuring competence in LP. The search yielded 167 articles. A combination of relevant Medical Subject Headings (MeSH) and/or keywords were used in the search strategies (details are available from the authors on request). All titles were reviewed for possible inclusion, and 86 articles were obtained for further review. The reference sections of these articles were reviewed, and 8 additional articles were obtained. All articles obtained were reviewed for possible inclusion of a validated checklist; 5 articles included published checklists, as described in the introduction.11,14-17

sec.title: Checklist Development and Delphi Rounds
sec.p: A modified Delphi method, explained in more detail in a previous publication,18 was used to develop the adult LP checklist. A preliminary 20-item LP checklist was developed by 2 of the authors (DB and KB) based on their experience with teaching and performing LP (Table 1).

caption.p: Development of an Adult Lumbar Puncture Instruction and Assessment Checklist Using a Modified Delphi Method.

tr.td: Performs a preprocedure time-out immediately before procedure
• Confirms patient ID, procedure, and site by all members of team doing the procedure
• Confirms no allergy to local anesthetic
• Upright, leaning forward with feet supported
Palpates iliac crests and spinous processes L3, L4, L5
• Superior aspect on crest is L4 process
Palpates the L4/L5 interspace • Palpates midline, marks site with pen or indentation
Preps L4/L5 interspace and surrounding skin
• Using circular motion of scrub,a center to peripheral
Injects lidocaine at site of procedure
• Subcutaneous injection, wheal formation, then deeper into interspace
With stylet in place, inserts needleb
• Site in midline, immediately above lower spinous process
Feels for a “pop” sensation as it passes ligamentum flavum
Removes stylet and notes any fluid from needle
If no fluid, replaces stylet and inserts 3-5 mm deeper
• Redirects needle using a different angle
Applies flexible tube from manometer to needle hub, if measuring pressure
Fills tubes in appropriate sequential manner
• Amount of fluid in each tube depends on the tests that are being ordered
Pulls out the needle and gently applies pressure to site
• If manometer is used, removes the manometer before the needle
• Stylet is in place when needle is withdrawn
Disposes of needle and manometer in sharps container
Writes procedure note in appropriate space

fn.label: a
fn.p: Using either providone-iodide or other cleansing agent as approved at your health care site.

fn.label: b
fn.p: For a lumbar puncture in an adult, 20- to 22-gauge Quincke needle is commonly used.

fn.label: c
fn.p: Midline as defined by the midlongitudinal axis of the patient.

sec.title: Experts
sec.p: In all, 9 experts, 5 from Thomas Jefferson University and 4 from Christiana Care Health System, participated in this study (Table 2). The experts were chosen to provide a balance between inpatient and outpatient settings and primary care and subspecialty practices.

caption.p: Expert Demographics for the Development of an Adult Lumbar Puncture Procedure Checklist.

sec.title: Statistical Analysis
sec.p: The expert ratings were used to calculate internal consistency of the checklist using Cronbach’s α in SPSS statistical software (IBM, Armonk, NY). The study was reviewed by the institutional review boards at both institutions and granted exempt status.

sec.title: Results
sec.p: The preliminary checklist included 20 items (Table 1). In the first round of the Delphi process, all items were felt to be “somewhat important” or “mandatory” to the procedure because the mean scores were greater than 4 (range 5.3-7.0). Thus, all items remained on the checklist.

Based on the experts’ free-text comments during the first Delphi round, text was added to 5 items, revisions were made to 2 items, and text was added to and revised in 3 items (Table 1). A 20-item checklist was maintained. In the second Delphi round, the range of means was 5.8 to 7.0. All items had a median score of 7 except item 15, which had a median score of 6. No new item recommendations were made. Because the experts agreed on all items, the 20-item checklist was finalized (Table 1). The internal consistency coefficient using Cronbach’s α was 0.79.

sec.title: Discussion
sec.p: The authors describe the results of the first step of the validation process for the development of a checklist for teaching and assessing adult LP. A modified Delphi method involving a panel of 9 experts was used to develop this checklist.

During expert review, agreement was high and each item on the checklist met the inclusion requirements. Based on expert comments in Delphi round 1, text was added to and/or revised in 10 items. During round 2, the experts agreed with the checklist.

Consideration of experts’ comments revealed variation on the use of manometry and prep for aseptic technique. Manometry is an elective component of the procedure that is performed with the patient either in the decubital or upright position. Although some experts use chlorhexidine as a prep (cleansing component), current label warning indicates that chlorhexidine is not FDA approved for use in LPs. Therefore, another appropriate agent (eg, providone-iodide) should be used as a prep for LP.

The expert reviewers made no statement as to the use of or need for epinephrine mixed with the lidocaine during administration of local anesthesia. As a result, this was not included in the checklist. In addition, the expert reviewers made no comment on the gauge of needle to be used. However, others have noted that to prevent post-LP headache,10 the clinician should attempt to use the smallest caliber needle appropriate for the procedure.

The experts emphasized the need for the clinician to know the reason for the procedure because the amount of fluid taken is dependent on indication. Further comments from the experts included a discussion of contraindications for LP, which include uncorrected coagulopathy and increased intracranial pressure. It is incumbent on the clinician to perform a thorough history and physical prior to the procedure to assess for contraindications.

The expert reviewers made no statement as to the need for specific positioning after the completion of the LP. The tradition is that the patient be placed in a supine position to prevent the development of post-LP headache. However, a recent review by Ahmed et al10 demonstrated that there is little evidence to support the efficacy of this positioning.

Previously published LP procedure checklists that were found in the literature show significant differences in the validation processes used when compared with the authors’ checklist. The checklist described by Lammers et al11 used experts from 1 discipline only and from 1 hospital in an unblinded manner for use in a simulation center. The checklist described by Conroy et al14 used a modified version of the checklist by Lammers et al.11 The checklist described by Lenchus and colleagues15,16 was adapted from the procedure video by Graham et al19 and vetted in an unblinded manner by a group of faculty from several disciplines. The checklist by Gaies et al17 was developed by expert clinical faculty from critical care and emergency medicine in an unblinded manner. The authors’ checklist was developed using the Delphi method for validation. This involves an iterative process of review by experts that is designed to achieve consensus.20 The experts are blinded to the identity of the other experts to prevent any 1 individual from influencing the group’s decisions about items.21 In addition, the experts who participated were from multiple institutions, primary care and subspecialty fields, and both inpatient and outpatient clinical care settings.

The authors’ checklist is used as a part of a longitudinal simulation and clinical skills attainment and structured practice curriculum. For this checklist to become further validated, it should be implemented and studied in the simulation and clinical environments. In the future, the authors intend to apply this checklist to the simulation and clinical environments for teaching and assessing this invasive skill.

Limitations of the study include the possibility of expert bias. However, as indicated previously, the experts were drawn from 2 institutions and 5 specialties to minimize institutional and specialty bias. In addition, the number of experts involved is similar to the number who participated in a previous study by Huang et al22 in their validation of a central venous catheter insertion checklist. The institutions in the current study are located in the same geographic region. Therefore, biases inherent in practice patterns of this region may have influenced the results. Finally, this checklist is designed for the performance of a LP in adults only; a checklist for pediatric LP should be developed by experts from pediatrics.

sec.title: Conclusion
sec.p: The authors describe the results of the first step of the validation process for the development of a checklist for teaching and assessing adult LP. A modified Delphi method involving a panel of 9 experts was used to create a checklist for this invasive procedure. Using a validated checklist could lead to fewer complications, decreased cost, and an overall increase in the quality of health care provided. Future studies should further validate this LP checklist by implementing and studying it in the simulation and clinical environments.
